comments.commentBody:
These were delicious - a wonderful corn flavor. If you are like me, and have had trouble getting your tortilla out of the press, try using parchment as the liner. I did that today, and was able to form beautiful tortillas with this dough.
I would quibble, though, that its enough for a taco party. This recipe fed my family of 3, but with no leftovers.
We used these tacos with Deb's (smitten kitchen) charred corn tacos - and it was a big hit.
Does baseball have anything to do with your avatar?  That guy did show up with Gil Hodges on "What's My Line?" in 1963.  Probably his six (at least) portrayals of today's hero has more to do with it.

If you increase the oven temp to 450, preheat the baking sheet in the oven, toss the zucchini slices with a splash or two of oil (enough to just barely coat them), and roast them on a bottom rack, you'll get the same browning (on the bottom side of each slice) as in the photo.

"What is one actionable change you would implement to enhance the college experience on campus?" Stop raising prices. Stop turning our kids' lives into indentured servitude for one or two decades or more.

the guy bungled the "parable". the parable, as i've heard it, is that the MBA tells the fisherman that if he borrows money and buys a better boat and fishes more hours a day he can make a lot of money--and then he can retire and go fishing in the AM and hang out with his family the rest of the day. the fisherman just looks at him like he's nuts. after all, that's exactly what the fisherman is already doing...

"Accomplish little", when referring to the fisherman, includes a value judgment that spending quality time with family and, presumably, have a strong family life, is not an accomplishment. If, in fact, this is the wording used in the class, perhaps it should be reconsidered? A strong family life counts for many as an "accomplishment."
A very fair game comment = differential between wisdom and knowledge. Or say data and information.

No but we are not talking about mathematical prowess here but the claim that "engineers can do anything a liberal arts majors can do but liberal arts major cannot do what an engineer can do." Clearly if a liberal arts major can handle the mathematics load of an engineering major then the above claim is false.

Yes, that is the natural consequence of a major that does not lead to direct employment, not surprising nor an original comment.

Yet most philosophy majors and most college graduates in general will likely end up in a job that does require a degree down that road, historically speaking. http://www.newyorkfed.org/research/current_issues/ci20-1.pdf. Chart 4 will show that even in 1990 ~50% of recent graduates were un or underemployed. But that rate dropped to ~30% by the time those graduates reached 35.

I agree with your recommendations regarding statistics.  However most life doesn't require much more than algebra. A few years ago I threw away my calculus notes from 1975 because it was apparent, that,  although it was my writing, I no longer understood them.

One problem with all of these sorts of advice columns is that they are supposedly for everybody, but are really only for a select subset of young people who, maybe, read the New York Times often enough to see an article like this, but, who, more likely, were shown it by their parents, or a guidance counselor, or a high school teacher, perhaps.

As such, these articles are already geared towards those who want to excel, or whose parents hope they do. Hence, the examples given, by both the author, who "just happens" to be somebody who made a very successful career out of job and vocational guidance, and in the other examples he uses, of those who succeeded at a national level, way beyond the successes that 99% of Americans will ever achieve. To expect to succeed in Hollywood like Richard Linklater did, as an example of somebody who went in "the arts" is simply to promise false hopes to millions.

In truth, most of us are mediocre, and don't strive for excellence, as the phrase in the 1980s had it. We stumble through college, then stumble through jobs, until, sometimes, we find we have a particular ability which helps us get a better job within our business, or company, or place of employment. But for many of us, even this doesn't happen. Many of us simply stumble through our lives, and are glad when we have a place to live, friends, maybe a family we provide for, and an okay job. This IS success for many of us. Our "major" is getting through life in one piece.

But,  if in that process the non-STEM majors learn discernment and the ability to choose wisely, then,  perhaps they will have better tools with which to negotiate life.  Technical fields change and what was considered good preparation at one point in time becomes less valuable (e.g. being the best buggy whip maker at the time that the automobile was becoming more popular and affordable was not a virtue).  Knowing how to adapt is key.

The late Steve Irwin and his family, all conservationists and animal lovers, believed that people will care more about animals if they can get up-close and personal with them.  While visiting their family zoo in Beerwah, Queensland, Australia shortly after 9/11, it was easy for me to see the profound impact that the human/animal interactions were having on the zoo's visitors.  While there, I was able to hold and stroke a koala, pet a camel and kangaroos and get nose to beak with an emu.  Though I was separated from their crocodiles by a strong fence, I was able to get within just a few feet of them.  That experience gave me a greater appreciation for Australia's unique animals.  If we ban horse racing, retire all of New York's carriage horses and put an end to New York's mounted police, how many city dwellers will ever be able to interact and appreciate those magnificent animals?  Once all of our close contact with animals is ended, how many people will really care about them anymore?

PETA did an expose of the cruel sport of racing not too long ago. They exposed the doping of horses so that they run and don't feel the pain of injuries they have, even one horse was forced to run even though his feet were in terrible shape. Often this is not revealed to the owners, who think the horses are being well cared for. Not to mention the cruelty of carriage horses in NYC, broken down beings made to live in a concrete jungle and never stand on grass, a life of suffering of intelligent beings to entertain the ignorant and non caring public. When will we treat animals well and with respect? When will we repay them for all they give us? When will we honor them?
I enjoyed the PandA. Like others I found it easier than normal so it was a romp and a pounce. Still great fun!

So THAT'S the problem! All these illegal immigrants snapping up those well-paying management-trainee jobs that college graduates would otherwise be getting!

Krugman is well-paid because he has rare talent and skills to go with his Nobel Prize in Economics. College graduates from good schools with records that reflect intelligence, industry, and the acquisition of relevant knowledge experience little difficulty generating job offers. College graduates who attended lightly-regarded institutions with records that put them in the bottom half of their class certainly face difficulties in the current improving, but not robust, economy. Neither of these groups, though, are being passed over so that employers can hire illegal immigrants, the vast majority of whom lack the essential skills and language ability--not to mention documentation--necessary to be hired for any but the most menial jobs. Those same immigrants, however, working as day laborers, janitors, maids, cooks, etc., contribute to aggregate demand with their meager consumption which adds to economic activity and output.

(By the way, the "structural changes" the Chicago School advocates have nothing whatever to do with recent college graduates or with immigrants. It presumes that unemployed workers lack the skills needed for all those great jobs just going begging. Workers with such skills, however, are not seeing fast-rising wages, negating the presumption.)

and Elke
John- your avatar was brought to the Stratford Festival to play King Lear by
Robin Phillips (who just died) who was DIR of the theatre then. I used to know more, but the LITTLE GREY CELLS are tired.

.
It seems to me this guy had some blunt words -- on national TV -- for one of the actresses from "Murder on the Orient Express" (film version starring recent grid entry Albert FINNEY as HERCULE POIROT) (I've also seen the Suchet version, however).

Rex decided he wasn't going to take it anymore?

Dino Grandoni could write about me not posting to my own private website (harmsen.net) about how I'm not having a baby and it would be every bit as fascinating as this article about Mark Zuckerberg posting about having a baby on his own private website (facebook.com).   What's worthy of investigation is why so many of the internet's homeless naively and compulsively contribute so much of their personal info and drivel to Mark Zuckerberg's private website.   They could instead follow my and Mark's good example by each getting their own domain where each would have responsibility and control.  Dino Grandoni could then write a billion articles about something equally dull that we each post to our respective own private websites, with a billion smiling pictures of us all.   It's not often an article is so dull and hopelessly irrelevant that it deserves comment for that.

He doesn't understand Austrian economics, because it is not understandable, the worst sort of incoherent wordiness. (Something that maths as against mathiness would combat).

1. Huh? What do you mean exactly by "money". You do realise that in insolvence, money is destroyed?
2. "... Misconception that the size of business-to-business supply-side is anything close to the size of business-to-consumer" interface" - in which economy and when? And why is this important?

By the way to channel Robert Waldmann - it is not obvious that having a (wrong) micro-foundation is better than not having one.

The pot is calling the kettle black
http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/08/11/friedman-and-the-austrians/

What's even more striking is that you didn't understand Austrian economics. You actually thought that the quote proves liquidationism when the key take-home of Prices and Production is that original means of production are fully employed after the adjustment. You couldn't have missed the message more profoundly, which means that you ridiculed something you didn't get.

Austrian economics rests on both a micro-foundation a relatively math-less and intuitive model of the business cycle. Hayek's model predicts why price level stabilization efforts by the Fed after a demand shock would lead to a sluggish economy with a concentrated, less diversified supply-side creating a large pool of idling workers and capacity.

You need to over-come two misconceptions:
1) The reswitching critique assumes that rates can reach the ZLB. Without a fiat-emitting fractional reserve bank subsidising central bank that would never happen. Sound adjustments to the business cycle require that the money supply remains stable, both to the up- or down-side!
2) How can a more capitalized supply-side produce output at a slower rate to match lower aggregate demand while keeping all original means fully employed? This counter-intuitive notion rests on the misconception that the the size of the business-to-business supply-side is anything close to the size of the business-to-consumer interface.

I eft out "v" in the denominator, corrections below:

if running delta_v is positive and (v + delta_v)/v > (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so run off the walkway.

if paused delta_v is -v so (v + delta_v)/v < (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so pause on the walkway.

I think this makes sense but not sure.... whichever time interval in which you are going proportionally faster will have a better average velocity over the distance.

v - walking velocity
delta_v - increase or decrease in velocity
u - walkway speed

off walkway: (v + delta_v)/v
on walkway: (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)

if running delta_v is positive and (v + delta_v) > (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so run off the walkway.

if paused delta_v is -v so (v + delta_v) < (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so pause on the walkway.

I eft out "v" in the denominator, corrections below:

if running delta_v is positive and (v + delta_v)/v > (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so run off the walkway.

if paused delta_v is -v so (v + delta_v)/v < (u + v + delta_v)/(u + v)
so pause on the walkway.

The gut micro-biome is causing the author's toddler to demand waffles and Go-gurt?

I give you points for an imaginative "reach", but little else.

Funny how the "picky kids" all manage very well to eat candy, sweets, bread, waffles, "white foods" and generally sugary, soft carbs.

I can remember going through that. As an adult, I've had to revert to eating like that sometimes, to balance how digestion works. My theory for me is about needing a rebalancing or repopulation of the gut microbiome, especially because the first time I did this as a kid was after having had chickenpox.

So maybe needing the gut microbiome to function healthfully is part of this picture. Maybe one reason for emotional dysfunction during period like this is due to nutrients not being absorbed fully. Maybe another is the gut microbiome is involved in production of chemicals, in the gut, that affect the brain.

I am also Asian American. I sympathize with the sentiment that we can always use more content specific to Asian Americans, but I definitely disagree that Liu needs to change his art to suit our politics. (

As an Asian American whose parents are recent immigrants, he miss the historical events that has shaped Asian American Culture, while concentrating on events that are several thousand years old.  How vibrant would the story be if it was told from the perspective of nineteenth century Asia, when during the building of the Rail Roads after the Civil War, that of a Character being shanghaied and brought to the US in order to being hired as a Coolie laborer for the Rail Road.  A time when Asians were meet with hostility and lunch mobs, and Exclusion Acts by the government, how did this impact on Asia and Asians as a whole?  Does the author have any knowledge of Asian American history, to justify not writing about the history of immigrants coming to the shore of North American in the past three hundred years?

What we have seen is the media coverage of Ms. Clinton, and a great deal of questioning her credibility. It is of course to the GOP advantage to keep this in the media. What the Times has not done, was investigate the charges and show it they are true or not. The Times did an investigation of Benghazi, but the GOP continues to say she is responsible for the death of the ambassador there.

A large percentage of the Democratic voters doubt her veracity, but the NYT has not looked into any of the charges. They are remiss in doing so. It is hard to say at this time if she can even get the nomination, and how she will fare against JEB, if he gets the nomination. The personal email issue can be a serious problem, or just something the GOP can use to discredit her. What are the facts. I take her answer to the XL Pipeline to be, "If I get elected, then I will have to look at the facts, am not making up my mind at present."

She has been under constant attack in the WSJ for the past two years, since she became the assumed frontrunner. To be fair the NYT should do an in depth analysis, and give her and her supporters a chance to refute the spurious ones.

I know quite a few Liberals who think she is dishonest, what are the facts regarding these charges, what are her connections to Wall Street? Are the Sanders charges valid? All I see is opinions and what could be called conspiracy theories. Give us the facts, not the opinions of those with and ax to grind.

The marvels of Myanmar were discovered by Hillary Clinton. She immediately passed them on to Obama who soon after made the first trip of an American President to visit the Generals. So what is so hot about Myanmar? Aung San Suu Kyi? Or its main export product, Heroin. This little country produces 20% of the world supply with the rest coming from our puppet state, Afghanistan.

Immediately after our political embrace of Myanmar and its Generals, the supply of heroin flooded America and the price dropped.

So do you think we are going to pounce on the Generals about the Rohingyas? Or start a war? The "humanitarian catastrophe" that Prof Sharma talks about is real, but so are the millions of refugees we created in the Middle East. Weigh the economic value of these non-conforming Moslems against one or two hundred billions of dollars annually and see who wins. That's the sum of our species.
Actually it also produces a lot of gemstones, cheap because they're mined with slave labor.

Why the Myanmarese military junta,  that's stubbornly opposed to democratic reforms and complicit with the forces responsible for the plight of the Rohingyas, shouldn't be censured and pressurised by the UN and international community for causing the humanitarian catastrophe of this magnitude to the Rohingyas,  an ethnic Muslim minority community, welcome neither to their own land of residence  nor to the countries having a preponderance of the Muslims?

Kip,

I suppose the most straightforward thing would be to write Glover Park directly. If the donor(s) wouldn't mind being outed, you might even get an answer. My guess is the Steyer machine is behind it.

But could you imagine the consternation and speculation about fossil fuel funding if a flamboyant PR campaign were to accompany the release of a paper claiming a non-threatening climate future?
